Award.AwardTitle: Improving Ocean Access for Research and Teaching at the Gulf of Maine Research Institute
Award.AbstractNarration:
The intense annual cycle and strong tides make the Gulf of Maine ecosystem incredibly productive, and it supports a high biomass of fish, whales, and seabirds. This ecosystem has historically been home to highly productive fisheries, including the fishery for Atlantic cod that was critical to the founding of the nation. This ecosystem is now warming at four times the global average rate, and this warming combined with generations of overfishing has led to the collapse of the region's iconic cod fishery. The Gulf of Maine Research Institute (GMRI) is the only institution dedicated to understanding the Gulf of Maine ecosystem. Scientists at GMRI conduct integrated, interdisciplinary research across the food web, from plankton to people. Beginning in 2019, this team will include students participating in a new NSF REU program. Much of GMRI's field research involves collecting fish ranging in size from juvenile alewife a few centimeters long to 2 meter-long bluefin tuna. These standard-sized chest freezers are now scattered throughout the building, creating an inefficient use of space and energy.

While GMRI is located on the waterfront in Portland, ME, the institute does not have direct access to the water. Furthermore, as the pace of sampling has increased, GMRI has had to add additional capacity to store frozen specimens. This project will fund the construction of a 12'-by-24' floating dock to provide safe access to the water for scientists, students, and marine educators. It will also fund acquisition of a large (8'-by-20') walk-in freezer to provide efficient storage of frozen specimens for research and teaching. The two projects supported by this funding were identified as part of a comprehensive strategic plan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Gulf of Maine Research Institute (GMRI) conducts interdisciplinary research on the ecosystems of the Gulf of Maine and in Casco Bay. Despite being located on the waterfront, scientists based at GMRI, including two research groups from the University of Maine, did not have direct access to the water. Funding from the National Science Foundation supported the construction of a floating dock and ADA-compliant gangway. GMRI?s two coastal research vessels are now berthed on the dock, providing convenient and safe access to the waters around Portland. 

The GMRI and University of Maine field research teams focus on understanding the biology and ecology of commercial fish. This requires the storage of a large number of frozen samples and whole fish. To support the growth of this work, NSF funds allowed the purchase of a large walk-in freezer. The freezer replaces several chest freezers that were stored in the lab. It also allows for the storage of whole specimens of large fish including sharks and tuna. 

The freezer and floating dock were used extensively by students in GMRI?s Research Experience for Undergraduates program last summer (this year?s program is running virtually due to the COVID-19 pandemic). The freezer was also being used to store whole specimens of highly migratory species (tuna, sharks) , allowing Dr. Walt Golet to share these animals through his dissections with Maine middle school students through the GMRI?s LabVenture Program, the Maine State Science Fair, and UMaine graduate and undergraduate students.  The freezer and float are being used this summer by GMRI and UMaine teams to support research on bluefin tuna, ongoing monitoring of the Casco Bay ecosystem, and new NSF-funded research on how environmental DNA can be used to monitor fish populations. The dock and the freezers were anticipated to be used in 2020 for a field-based fisheries techniques class, which has now been rescheduled for 20201.  The dock will allow students on the water access to participate in several modules directed at hands-on fisheries-based learning.  The freezer will be used to store specimens for class modules related to foraging ecology, age/growth, and general physiology and morphology studies.
